sectionTitle: Some Caveats Regarding Financial Planning Models

columns.text:
The question will require us to analyze the external financing and retention ratio, assuming that the sales growth is 15% and the firm has a projected EFN.

1. What does it mean concerning the internal growth rate?

2. What does it mean to sustainable growth?

3. What will happen to the projected EFN if the retention ratio increases?

4. What if the retention ratio decreases?

5. What happens to the projected EFN if the firm pays out all of its earnings in the form of dividends?

### Let's first identify the given data in the problem.

1. Testaburger Inc. uses no external financing and maintains a positive retention ratio.

2. The sales growth is expected at 15%, and the firm's projected EFN will be negative.

## Requirement 1. 

### The relationship of the sales growth of 15% and the negative projected EFN to the internal growth rate.

A negative projected EFN assumes that there is a surplus of internal financing. Since there is an excess in the internal funding, it will show that the internal growth rate will be more than 15%.

## Requirement 2. 

### The relationship of the sales growth of 15% and the negative projected EFN to the sustainable growth rate.

If the internal growth rate is expected to be greater than 15%, the sustainable growth rate will be higher compared to the internal growth rate. The sustainable growth rate is always higher than the internal growth rate because we maintain a constant debt-equity ratio.

## Requirement 3.

### The possible effect to EFN when the retention ratio increases.

The relationship of the EFN to the retention ratio is inversely proportional; as the retention ratio increases, the EFN will continue to decline because an increased retention ratio will give us an internal source of funding.

## Requirement 4.

### The possible effect to EFN when the retention ratio decreases.

The relationship of the EFN to the retention ratio is inversely proportional; as the retention ratio decreases, the EFN will continue to increase because a decreased retention ratio will give us a negative internal source of funding, resulting in an external funding source.

## Requirement 5. 

### The possible effect to EFN when all the net income is declared a dividend.

When all of the net income is declared as a dividend, there will be no additional retained earnings, resulting in no internal funding source. In effect, the EFN will increase because there is now a possible need to sustain the company's financial goals.
